awd_titl_txt: Pathways into Careers in Information Technology: Community College Student Decision-Making about Academic Programs and Jobs
awd_abstract_narration:
Graduates of technician programs have opportunities to enter well-paying, high-demand careers.  However, only 20% of community college students complete their programs of study within six years.  Prior research highlights the challenges facing students at community colleges.  However, the career development literature includes little research on community college students and their decision-making processes.  The literature is even more lacking about community college students in technician fields.  The goal of this research project is to increase understanding of the decisions students make in pursuing credentials (e.g., degrees and certificates) at two-year institutions, and in pursuing careers in information technology.   The research focuses on Information Technology (IT) because it offers students a wide-array of opportunities and specialties.  In addition, many two-year institutions have developed IT programs to address the growing need for IT professionals.  Relying on multiple sources of data, the project brings together a multidisciplinary team to investigate student decision-making.  

This quantitative and qualitative mixed methods research project will examine how students' experiences and information resources influence their decision making, particularly early in their enrollment in college, and how that process evolves over time.  The longitudinal and cross-sectional mixed methods study takes a multidisciplinary theoretical approach, drawing on literature from career development, psychology, sociology, and economics.  The study employs a variety of research methods, including student surveys, in-depth longitudinal student interviews, point-in-time interviews with faculty and administrators, secondary data analysis of administrative records, site visits, and document analysis.  The quantitative and qualitative data collection and analyses are designed to investigate, triangulate, test, and confirm findings. The research project is designed to generate knowledge useful to students, the public, community college/technician education professionals, and policy-makers committed to increasing student success in advanced technological programs and to meeting the demand for a middle skills workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Students in Ivy Tech Community College’s Information Technology programs, like other community college and technical students nationally, have multiple career pathways available to them. While these choices offer opportunity, they also create a confusing array of options students must navigate. Understanding how students make decisions about their education and career is imperative to offering better institutional support and resources and may lead to improved retention and completion.

This project engaged mixed methods to gather an understanding of student decision-making. We surveyed students through their IT classes and from these surveys identified two subgroups for analysis including a longitudinal sample that we interviewed over time and a beginner sample who started their education during the early COVID-19 pandemic. We also used institutional data to identify students who had completed an IT program for an additional subgroup of interviewees. In addition to the student perspective, we also surveyed and interviewed faculty and advisors about their perspectives on student decision-making. Based our data from these various data sources, some broad trends emerge.

Participants in the Longitudinal sample (followed from 2019-21) were found to begin program and career considerations broadly, seeking information from multiple sources and relying largely on general and open-sourced information. Over time, students became more engaged with and targeted in information-seeking. At times, students, who often relied on non-institutional information sources from the internet and their social networks, had incomplete information about IT education and careers. Culture, family, social networks, and workplace connections/experiences all played a role in students’ decision making. Early interest in IT combined with an IT-related hobby, especially for those with a high sense of self-efficacy, seemed to propel these students toward IT careers and in many ways helped them gain entry. Financial considerations as well as geographic location played a role in whether students continued to pursue IT education or careers.

            Other work from the project suggests that students rely on different types of information sources (personal social networks, institutional networks, internet research) for different types of decisions. This study looked at the information seeking habits of two groups of students, program completers and program beginners to understand how they used information when making decisions about programs as well as careers. For example, when making programmatic decisions students relied heavily on advisors and the Ivy Tech website to understand their options and pathways. When looking for advice about careers they would seek out faculty and do their own research online. It’s important to understand the strategic ways that community college students seek out information.

We also found that faculty and advisors worked together to help dispel students’ confusion about what a computer science degree really is. These groups provided distinct, but often overlapping and related, information to students; and have moved away from a hand-off model of advising to become more collaborative in their advising practices. Strong communication between faculty and advisors and on-campus events are two promising practices for improving the student advising experience.

In a report focused on the impact the pandemic had on student experiences we bring together the perspective of advisors and faculty in addition to student voice to understand the ways that the COVID-19 pandemic had on online learning and virtual advising. We find overall that students had mixed experiences with online learning, those who had hands-on learning styles faced more challenges. We also found that while virtual advising offered a promise of increased access and convenience, overall based on our survey data, students sought advising less during the pandemic.

In addition to these above findings from our reports, our team also worked on some issue briefs. One of these briefs explored the connection between short-term workforce funding and student decision making and the need for more research into these programs to understand their outcomes. Another issue brief looked at demographics and student decision-making within Ivy Tech’s IT programs. This brief found that people of color were largely underrepresented in Ivy Tech IT program enrollment and most students were younger men, while women who were enrolled were more likely to be both older and more educated. As evidenced from our data the underrepresentation of women and people of color in Ivy Tech Community College IT programs is apparent. Data also revealed that female IT students in our sample may have had specialized needs and faced more significant challenges than their male counterparts.

 


Last Modified: 04/10/2024
Modified by: Michelle Van Noy
